reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central optimism channel in the essay: that (post-)AGI conditions will allow meaningful reflection, bargaining, and moral trade/compromise to steer outcomes toward mostly-great futures (esp. sections 2.3 and 3). If instead the decisive window is very compressed and early lock-in/first-mover dynamics dominate, that would substantially undercut the ‘trade and compromise’ route and some of the essay’s updated optimism. However, the essay already flags closely related blockers (early lock-in, power concentration, decisions made soon, threats) and explicitly notes that selection/growth effects might not have time to operate, so the critique is partly “priced in” rather than a novel refutation. The critique’s strength is therefore moderate: it highlights a real failure mode but does not supply much argument or evidence that the window is in fact so decisively early that trade is mostly irrelevant, nor that trade can’t still matter among post-lock-in subagents or within a dominant coalition. The main empirical claim (capabilities races compress timelines, enabling early lock-in and reducing bargaining leverage) is plausible but uncertain and somewhat overstated (‘bargains from zero’). It is clearly stated, focused on one issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: Capability races may lock in outcomes before meaningful moral bargaining can occur
